Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.raw_text: Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (1974) (discussing warranty of habitability and tenant remedies).
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: - Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (1974) (discussing warranty of habitability and tenant remedies).
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that California recognizes a common law implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and extensively discusses the tenant’s remedies, including asserting breach of that warranty as a defense in unlawful detainer and the method for calculating rent abatement/damages. The court’s reasoning and explicit statements directly match the proposition that Green addresses the warranty of habitability and tenant remedies.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “We have concluded that a warranty of habitability is implied by law in residential leases in this state and that the breach of such a warranty may be raised as a defense in an unlawful detainer action. Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. … If the trial court does find a breach of implied warranty, the court must then determine the extent of the damages flowing from this breach.”

Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.raw_text: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979) (discussing landlord obligations and tenant remedies).
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.proposition: - Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979) (discussing landlord obligations and tenant remedies).
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly and extensively discusses modern landlord obligations—specifically the implied warranty of habitability under N.Y. Real Property Law § 235-b—and the corresponding tenant remedies, including rent abatement and the measure of damages. It characterizes a residential lease as a sale of shelter and services, makes the tenant’s duty to pay rent dependent on habitability, and approves a percentage rent reduction as a remedy, thus squarely supporting the proposition that the case discusses landlord obligations and tenant remedies.
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.relevant_excerpt: “A residential lease is now effectively deemed a sale of shelter and services by the landlord who impliedly warrants: first, that the premises are fit for human habitation… The obligation of the tenant to pay rent is dependent upon the landlord’s satisfactory maintenance of the premises in habitable condition… the proper measure of damages for breach of the warranty is the difference between the fair market value of the premises if they had been as warranted… and the value of the premises during the period of the breach.”

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..raw_text: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I. 1984) (recognizing tenant remedies where landlord breach of essential services affects habitability).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..proposition: - Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I. 1984) (recognizing tenant remedies where landlord breach of essential services affects habitability).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts an implied warranty of habitability for residential leases and then details tenant remedies when the landlord’s failure to maintain essential facilities renders the premises uninhabitable. It holds that tenants may recover rent previously paid, obtain damages (including for discomfort), withhold future rent, and use repair-and-deduct, all where defects in essential services affect habitability. This directly supports the proposition that the case recognizes tenant remedies when a landlord’s breach of essential services affects habitability.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..relevant_excerpt: “[W]e now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease… that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. Because we hold that the lease of a residential dwelling creates a contractual relationship… the standard contract remedies of rescission, reformation and damages are available… The tenant will be liable only for ‘the reasonable rental value [if any] of the property in its imperfect condition during his period of occupancy.’ … [T]he tenant may withhold the payment of future rent.”
